title: 9 Asian American Jews speak
message:
In partnership with Rabbi Mira Rivera of Romemu in New York, N.Y., we’ve asked nine Asian American Jewish leaders to share their experiences in this painful time, as well as thoughts on how American Jews can and should offer support to the Asian American community.
The Jewish community must stand tall and proud in solidarity with Asian American communities everywhere, and with meaningful recognition of those in our own community who are both Asian and Jewish.
The identities, voices and work of Asian Jews must be elevated to more than just a footnote.
There are incredible stories out there shared by Asian American Jews, such as through LUNAR: The Jewish-Asian Film Project.
To share your own experiences as an Asian American Jew, contact interim opinion editor Talya Zax at [email protected] or opinion intern Zachariah Sippy at [email protected].

title: Speakers , venue pull out of prominent activist group pro - Christian nationalist conference
message:
Recommended VideosMultiple speakers and a venue have pulled out of a prominent Texas activist group’s July conference after The Texas Tribune reported on its plans to amplify white nationalist figures and rhetoric.
In an email to supporters on Thursday, True Texas Project founder Julie McCarty said that the venue “went back on their agreement” to host the event.
Formerly known as the NE Tarrant Tea Party, True Texas Project was crucial in the rise of Texas’ ultraconservative movement throughout the 2010s.
“You’re not going to demographically replace a once proud, strong people without getting blow-back," responded her husband, Fred McCarty, who is also a True Texas Project leader.
Kevin Stitt will take the stage at The Texas Tribune Festival, Sept. 5–7 in downtown Austin.
